explanation_before: Here are my arguments: Health risks: Obesity increases the risk of a variety of health problems, including cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, certain cancers and orthopedic problems.Biological Complexity: Obesity is influenced not only by individual choices, but also by complex biological factors, genetic predispositions and environmental conditions, which make it difficult to attribute it to personal failure alone.Need for Interventions: The recognition of obesity as Illness facilitates access to medical care, therapy and preventative measures to improve individual health and reduce the burden on the healthcare system.

explanation_after: I agree slightly- as intellectual property rights protect individuals and businesses creative ideas and allows them to realise these ideas. However, there are some arguments against these rights, for example some sources say they "stifle creativity".

explanation_before: In my opinion, intellectual property rights should exist to secure the safety of product idea of artist, medics, etc. The safety of ideas is highly motivating for many people and can lead to many innovative ideas.
explanation_after: I still believe that intellectual property rights are very important because they are a key factor in securing data and spirit of innovative people. During the Covid19 pandemic, many countries raised the negative effects of property rights since it made it harder for medics to produce the vaccination and fight against the pandemic. On the other hand the founder of the vaccination was able to secure his idea.

explanation_before: Intellectual property rights should exist as it is important as physical property rights. Intellectual property can be stolen as any other and thats why it is important to have rights to protect it.
explanation_after: I believe that intellectual property rights should exist as ideas are one of the most valuable contributions for businesses and society itself. I think there should be patents on the ideas to protect individuals who came up with those ideas as they can be profitable or they can create a respect in the society.

explanation_before: Yes, if intellectual property does not exist then there would not be any incentive for the creation or invention of new products or services. One of the most important examples is the patents in the medical field, if there is no economic incentive, then companies won't invest in R&D for developing new treatments or vaccines. Overall should exist as it encourages innovation.

explanation_before: I replied neutrally because the subject is complicated; the uniforms in schools prevent seeing a difference in the outfits of the students, which means kids don't have to worry about their looks as much, or how expensive or cheap their clothes are compared to the ones other kids use. On the other hand, wearing a uniform restricts a person's individuality. This means that the person can no longer express themselves through clothing.

explanation_before: The definition of a clinically relevant illness is closely entangled with dysfunctional behavior/physical processes, suffering and deviation from norms. The average population is not obese. In addition, many studies prove a connection between obesity and high blood pressure, etc.
explanation_after: Further connections between obesity and damaging physical values.

explanation_before: School uniforms take away from the students individual expressions and also often force them into a binary system (girls wear skirts, boys wear trousers). Also, they can be fairly expensive, which can be a financial burden for the parents
explanation_after: While uniforms can be expensive, they also stop students from flaunting their wealth through their clothes, making everybody seems equal, which can be a positive thing. However, I still think that self expression is more important

explanation_before: They shouldn't because forcing students - often times teenagers - to wear a uniform hinders them in developing a sense of self and learning to exress themselves through their clothing. The often brought up argument that uniforms would decrease bullying is invalid because people who bully others will always find a reason to do that.
explanation_after: As uniforms are becoming increasingly expensive they do not make students feel more like a "family" as stated in the articles. They also do not diminish bullying  because of looks as is declared but in some cases uniforms can act as a provocation. So if some students uniforms don't conform to the school's standard (f.ex. they can't afford to buy new uniforms and have to wear the old ones that maybe have holes or are discolored because of everyday usage and frequent washing) they may face humiliation through other students mocking them. So uniforms have the potential to become an educational barrier if students cannot go to class because they can't afford the demanded uniform. The oftenly named aspect of higher academic success at schools with uniforms cannot be generalized and one could argue that the diminished pressure of comparison through looks become the comparison of academic success.

explanation_before: Students shouldnt be forced to wear a certain type of clothing. Even tho i do understand the reason "school uniform so no one feels excluded because of different family backgrounds", i think its still limiting the freedom of students. Also i personally dont think a lot of students care as much about other students clothes as people might think.
explanation_after: School uniform creates an atmosphere of belonging for students and help identify other students more quickly. My opinion hasnt really changed on the topic: but i do understand why school decides for uniforms more.
I think even the experts don't agree.  After reading the articles, I'm no longer sure whether obesity can be classified as a disease.

explanation_before: So I think that feeling comfortable in your own clothes is a massive point while going to school. So I'm confident in what I wear and would still like to have that decision. But I can also see why school uniforms are a good thing because then families that have kids with less money are not bullied in school, because of what they wear.
explanation_after: I still have the same opinion. Personally I would think it's an disaster to not go to school with the ability to wear what you're used to and what you're comfortable in, but I know that for many it may be the other way around, that they ARE comfortable in school uniform, because they cannot be mocked for wearing something different. Then however you can also say that hairstyle is not always implied. So that can still influence other students or give them a reason to bully them.
